Award.AwardTitle: Forecasting and Control Methodology for Monitoring and Management of Chronic Diseases

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop broadly applicable methods to improve monitoring and management of patients with chronic diseases. The systems engineering based modeling methodology will generate effective predictions of disease progression over time. Further, they will be integrated with real-time feedback-driven forecasting and control/optimization algorithms to help clinicians determine the interval of time until a particular chronic disease patient should be monitored next or an intervention should be considered by a physician. The research links population-based knowledge to patient-specific information measurements taken sequentially to determine the optimum monitoring intervals. Preliminary research indicates that linear Gaussian system models are effective for modeling progression, but existing theory will be extended to include controlled observations that optimize the tradeoff between intervals that are too short or too long. By using data to generate partially observable state space models, and by using higher dimensional state spaces, we bring a new perspective to this problem.

The primary focus of this study is open-angle glaucoma, a major cause of blindness worldwide. If successful, the results of this research will indicate to clinicians when glaucoma progression has occurred and how chronic diseases such as glaucoma are likely to progress. In addition, our results will provide a recommendation on when to next monitor the patient. Such knowledge will improve the health outcomes of the population and also result in cost containment. The co-PIs will integrate these new methods into their courses and mentoring to impact graduate and undergraduate engineering students and medical students. Outcomes will be disseminated to engineering, public health, and medical communities through presentations and publications targeting highly visible journals in engineering and healthcare.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This National Science Foundation Award supported the development of a new decision support methodology that uses operations research (mathematical modeling) and statistics to improve monitoring and management of chronic disease patients. The research linked population-based knowledge and patient-specific information measurements to generate, at any point in time, effective predictions of disease evolution and progression. The models were created from major clinical trials for glaucoma to capture the disease evolution dynamics. As each patient is monitored, his/her test results are incorporated by the model to personalize the predictions of his/her disease evolution and make those predictions more accurate for that individual. Thus our models update at each visit (or test result) to suggest to the clinician an optimized future date at which that particular chronic disease patient should be monitored next. In addition to the ability to predict the evolution of the patient's disease, the optimized timing of monitoring/visits selected coincide with timely dates at which the clinical care provider needs to consider a possible change in the patient's treatment. 

Moreover, this model was enhanced to compute an optimized, personalized, and dynamically-updated target level of eye pressure that can help guide the clinician in selecting an efficacious treatment option. That is, we advise on how to best control the one and only controllable risk factor (eye pressure) and we leave it to the clinician to use their medical knowledge to determine how to achieve that level of eye pressure (e.g., which eye drop medication to use or which combinations). We also allow the determination of the optimal personalized timing of diagnostic tests to include the selection among multiple test options (e.g., standard automated perimetry, intraocular pressure, or both tests).  Our research built upon systems modeling and control theory that had not previously been applied to such physician-patient interactions and disease management.  By extending that methodology to optimize the relative change in disease progression, we opened the door to new applications.  We also showed that the classic "two-way separation principle" between estimation and control still applies to this new class of mathematical problems. The key implication is that this new methodology remains very efficient to compute, facilitating its application in new areas.

Our work was applied to open-angle glaucoma, a major cause of blindness in the US and worldwide. The models were parameterized using two large multi-center clinical trials involving patients with mild and advanced disease. We showed that, using our new methodology, it would be possible to detect glaucoma progression up to 57% sooner than following fixed yearly monitoring schedules. This research involved 4 PhD students, 1 master's student, 18 undergraduate students, and 1 medical student. It has been presented at both national and international conferences both in engineering and in ophthalmology. In addition, it has generated publications in top engineering and clinical journals. It won first prize of the international 2012 Doing Good With Good OR Award and first prize of the 2013 Medical Decision Making Lee Lusted Award for Quantitative Methods and Theoretical Developments. We have filed for a patent (13,668,280), developed a prototype teaching tool, and have started working towards integrating our algorithms into clinical practice.
